awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating Middle Grades Mathematics Teachers' Curricular Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration:
Teachers are crucial to improving mathematics instruction in the US. Improvements in understanding teachers' knowledge about mathematics for teaching have led to improvements in teacher education and professional development. However, there are gaps in the understanding of mathematics knowledge for teaching, including how teachers reason about curriculum. Because curricular resources, including textbooks, continue to be important resources and tools for teachers, understanding how teachers reason about curriculum are important to improve teachers' knowledge and instructional practice. This collaborative project with the University of Nevada Las Vegas, Brigham Young University, University of Arkansas, and Grand Valley State University, will study middle grade mathematics teachers' curricular reasoning and develop a taxonomy that can be used by curriculum developers, teacher educators and professional developers to help in the development of productive curricular reasoning for teachers. This research is funded by the EHR Core Research Program, which emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring:  STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. 

This three stage study will begin with adaptation, development, and pilots of the interview and observation protocols with eight teachers to verify that these instruments are valid and reliable. The second stage focuses on developing the curricular reasoning taxonomy by collecting analyzing interview and observation data from 12 grade 8 mathematics teachers in four states. These teachers will be using novel curriculum materials to teach geometry transformations during their regular classroom instruction. During this stage, the project will develop an initial taxonomy of teachers' curricular reasoning as they plan and enact these lessons. In the third stage, the researchers will verify and refine the curricular reasoning taxonomy by collecting interview and observation data from 20-40 grade 8 mathematics teachers in four states with a variety of teaching backgrounds.

por.por_cntn:
The project Collaborative Research: Investigating Middle Grades Mathematics Teachers Curricular Reasoning was co-directed by faculty at four institutions of higher education. The focus of this multi-stage project was to foundationally outline ways in which teachers reason through their practice. A specific lens of Curricular Reasoning was used throughout this project, which has been defined by Breyfogle et al. (2010) as ?the thinking processes that teachers engage in as they work with curriculum materials to plan, implement and reflect on instruction? (p. 308). Our project analyzed 8th grade mathematics teachers? planning and enacting of a sequence of unfamiliar mathematics lessons that are focused on mathematical disparities identified in the new curriculum purported to align with Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSSM).Our project outlined decisions made by teachers throughout the planning and enactment of 8th grade geometry lessons. Critically, our findings identified a need for researchers, teachers, teacher leaders, and other stakeholders to recognize mathematics content and mathematics curricula as importantly different elements of the classroom with respect to teaching mathematics. 

Our study included a total of 17 teachers from four U.S. states. Data were collected from lesson observation cycles that included an observed lesson and pre- and post-interviews with teachers discussing planning and reflection aspects of teaching mathematics lessons. Data from the lesson cycles were analyzed through qualitative research techniques to, over time and iterations, develop a robust framework onto which we could map teacher?s decisions and thinking processes they utilized throughout our study.

A major result of our study is the empirically-based Instructional Pyramid, a framework for understanding mathematics teacher?s decisions (an article explicating this framework was published by Investigations in Mathematics Learning in October 2021). This framework both advances, extends, and illuminates interconnectedness among a variety of research perspectives around the activity of teaching mathematics within the field of mathematics education.
